pull.title: Add more script edge condition tests.
pull.body: This pull request adds some tests to the script_valid.json and tx_invalid.json data which exercise more edge conditions that are not currently being tested.

events.message:
Add more script edge condition tests.

This commit adds some tests to the script_valid.json and tx_invalid.json
data which exercise more edge conditions that are not currently being
tested.

events.body:
Untested ACK-- I trust Travis exercised these new tests.
Should be merged quickly in my opinion, testing edge cases is a very good thing.

issue.title: Ensure "OP_0" and "false" have the same represenstation on stack
issue.body:
During the script execution via [executeScript](https://github.com/bitcoinj/bitcoinj/blob/5dcf6439755ac5db6e151ba4403b5d3e8bf792eb/core/src/main/java/org/bitcoinj/script/Script.java#L763) certain operations add boolean values to the stack.

Using Bitcoin Core as reference, in particular:
- `OP_EQUAL`: [bitcoin/.../script/interpreter.cpp#L676](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/48efbdbe986355bd2478f0fdd366b20952fbf30a/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L676)
- `OP_CHECKSIG`: [bitcoin/.../script/interpreter.cpp#L851](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/48efbdbe986355bd2478f0fdd366b20952fbf30a/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L851)
- `OP_CHECKMULTISIG`: [bitcoin/.../script/interpreter.cpp#L947](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/48efbdbe986355bd2478f0fdd366b20952fbf30a/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L947)

Boolean values, which are added to the stack as result, are represented as follows in Bitcoin Core:
- `true`: as vector with one element: `[1]`
- `false`: as empty vector with zero elements: `[]`

See:
- [bitcoin/.../script/interpreter.cpp#L244](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/48efbdbe986355bd2478f0fdd366b20952fbf30a/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L244)
- [bitcoin/.../script/interpreter.cpp#L246](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/48efbdbe986355bd2478f0fdd366b20952fbf30a/src/script/interpreter.cpp#L246)

However, in BitcoinJ the representation of `false` in these cases differs:

It is represented as Byte array with one element, which is zero: `[0]`

See:
- `OP_EQUAL`: [bitcoinj/.../script/Script.java#L1025](https://github.com/bitcoinj/bitcoinj/blob/5dcf6439755ac5db6e151ba4403b5d3e8bf792eb/core/src/main/java/org/bitcoinj/script/Script.java#L1025)
- `OP_CHECKSIG`: [bitcoinj/.../script/Script.java#L1304](https://github.com/bitcoinj/bitcoinj/blob/5dcf6439755ac5db6e151ba4403b5d3e8bf792eb/core/src/main/java/org/bitcoinj/script/Script.java#L1304)
- `OP_CHECKMULTISIG`: [bitcoinj/.../script/Script.java#L1381](https://github.com/bitcoinj/bitcoinj/blob/5dcf6439755ac5db6e151ba4403b5d3e8bf792eb/core/src/main/java/org/bitcoinj/script/Script.java#L1381)

At minimum this has an impact on the behavior of `OP_EQUAL` and `OP_EQUALVERIFY`, for example, when comparing something with `OP_FALSE`/`OP_0`, as follows:

How it should be:

```
   OP_FALSE OP_FALSE OP_TRUE         | OP_EQUAL OP_EQUAL
-> OP_FALSE OP_FALSE                 | OP_EQUAL
-> OP_TRUE

OK!
```

With values, in Bitcoin Core:

```
   [] [] [1]                         | OP_EQUAL OP_EQUAL
-> [] []                             | OP_EQUAL
-> [1]

OK!
```

With values, in BitcoinJ:

```
   [] [] [1]                         | OP_EQUAL OP_EQUAL
-> [] [0]                            | OP_EQUAL
-> [0]

ERROR!
```

@davecgh added exactly this case to the script unit tests via https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6112, which brought me to this discovery.

Related operations are `OP_DEPTH`, `OP_SIZE`, `OP_ADD`, `OP_SUB`, ... and friends, where a `false stack element` may appear, however these are ultimately handled by [encodeMPI](https://github.com/bitcoinj/bitcoinj/blob/9219d8a9b5714cf4e65dc046c70930c86416e65d/core/src/main/java/org/bitcoinj/core/Utils.java#L259-L262), which already produces correct `[]` elements.

This submisson attemps to fix the issue, to mirror the verification behavior of Bitcoin Core, by adding empty Byte arrays to the stack, instead of Byte arrays with `0`.

Note: this is consensus critical code, and I'm not really familiar with BitcoinJ! :) To verify the actual issue, [bitcoinj/.../script/script_valid.json#L401](https://github.com/dexX7/bitcoinj/blob/be41d84fb9d21bfbd978084cae3200552343717c/core/src/test/resources/org/bitcoinj/script/script_valid.json#L401) may be tested before applying the fix, to see the failure.

comments.body:
Nice!

Damn that's subtle, and also a malleability source come to think of it.

To be exact, any bits not covered by the 0x1f == SIGHASH_SINGLE mask can be changed at will w/o invalidating the signature. Not a major issue as the signer has to allow it to happen, but it's an interesting edge case that could come up in certain protocols if you can fool someone into somehow signing the hash 0x1 - conceivable in a multisig payment channel for instance.

Oh, actually I see what you're doing - this isn't related to the SIGHASH_SINGLE bug like I thought. You do successfully test what you think you're testing, but not in a realistic way. More realistic would be to create a test with a CHECKSIG in the scriptSig triggering this condition - that could be an actual tx with otherwise valid hashes.

What I thought you'd noticed was that the SIGHASH_SINGLE bug works regardless of the state of the other SIGHASH flags, something which I don't think anyone's noticed before.
